title: Honeywell to buy Sigma-Aldrich’s research chemicals business for €105m
text:
Honeywell to buy Sigma-Aldrich’s research chemicals business for €105m 21 October 2015 
US-based Honeywell has signed a definitive agreement to buy Sigma-Aldrich's Seelze, Germany-based laboratory research chemicals business for €105m. 
Under the deal, Honeywell will acquire three global products from Sigma, including Fluka chemicals and reagents, Hydranal Karl Fischer titration reagents, and Chromasolv high-purity solvents. 
Fluka chemicals and reagents are used for biochemical research and other chemical and pharmaceutical applications, Hydranal Karl Fischer titration reagents are used by laboratories to measure moisture content in liquids and solids, and Chromasolv is used for chromatography. "Customers of the Fluka, Hydranal, and Chromasolv brand solvents and inorganics will continue to get consistent, high-quality products from Honeywell." 
Sigma-Aldrich's research chemicals business is involved in developing and manufacturing high-purity research chemicals, and other materials for new drug discovery, medical diagnostic testing, and other laboratory applications. 
The new agreement is subject to customary closing conditions, including regulatory review. 
Honeywell Performance Materials and Technologies president and CEO Darius Adamczyk said: "The acquisition will enable Honeywell to offer a broader line of inorganic chemicals and solvents for demanding applications ranging from pharmaceutical drug discovery to medical diagnostic testing. 
"Customers of the Fluka, Hydranal, and Chromasolv brand solvents and inorganics will continue to get consistent, high-quality products from Honeywell. 
"The combination of Honeywell's manufacturing expertise with the strength of an expanded solvents and inorganics portfolio will enable us to better serve all of our customers in research chemicals." 
Honeywell will merge the newly acquired business with its chemical unit, known as Honeywell Fine Chemicals. 
For more than 100 years, the company has been supplying research chemicals and specialty organic and inorganic compounds to the chemical and pharmaceutical industries. 
It has laboratories and production facilities in Seelze, Germany and Muskegon, Michigan, US. 
Honeywell sells its products under the brand names Burdick & Jackson and Riedel-de Haen. 
The company's products are used in a variety of laboratory, consumer and industrial applications, such as drug discovery, toothpaste, water purification, fortified foodstuffs, polymer synthesis, and metal surface treatment and finishing. Follow Us:
